docs.title: 001. Getting Started with SQL Server
docs.text: This section helps you get started with SQL Server quickly and easily through these five introductory tutorials:

docs.title: 1. What is SQL Server
docs.text: Learn about the basics and key features of SQL Server.

docs.title: 2. Install SQL Server 2022 Developer Edition
docs.text: Step-by-step instructions to install SQL Server 2022 Developer Edition on your local computer or server.

docs.title: 3. Connect to the SQL Server
docs.text: Learn how to connect to SQL Server using SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).

docs.title: 4. Explore an SQL Server Sample Database
docs.text: Get introduced to the sample database provided for learning and practice.

docs.title: 5. Load Sample Database

docs.title: 001.001.What is SQL Server
docs.text: Home / 001_Getting_Started_with_SQL_Server / 001.001.What_is_SQL_Server

docs.title: 001.001. What is SQL Server
docs.text:
SQL Server is a relational database management system (RDBMS) developed and marketed by Microsoft.

Like other RDBMS platforms, SQL Server is built on SQL (Structured Query Language), the standard language for querying and managing relational databases. SQL Server uses Transact-SQL (T-SQL), Microsoft’s proprietary extension to SQL, which includes additional programming constructs.

Initially exclusive to Windows for over 20 years, SQL Server 2017, released in October 2017, was the first version to support both Windows and Linux environments.

docs.title: SQL Server Architecture
docs.text:
The following diagram illustrates the architecture of the SQL Server:

SQL Server architecture is composed of two main components:

  • Database Engine
  • SQLOS (SQL Server Operating System)

docs.title: 1. Database Engine
docs.text:
The Database Engine is the core of SQL Server. It includes:

  • Relational Engine: Also known as the query processor, it determines the optimal method to execute queries. It handles:

    • Memory management
    • Thread and task management
    • Buffer management
    • Distributed query processing

  • Storage Engine: Manages the storage and retrieval of data. It interacts with physical storage systems suchs as disks and Storage Area Networks (SANs).

The Database Engine also creates and manages database objects such as:

  • Stored procedures
  • Views
  • Triggers

docs.title: 2. SQLOS
docs.text:
SQLOS sits beneath the Relational and Storage Engines, providing essential operating system-level services, including:

  • Memory management
  • I/O management
  • Exception handling
  • Synchronization services

docs.title: SQL Server Services and Tools
docs.text: Microsoft bundles SQL Server with a suite of data management and business intelligence (BI) tools.

docs.title: Data Management Tools
docs.text:
• SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)
  • SQL Server Data Quality Services
  • SQL Server Master Data Services

docs.title: Development and Management Tools
docs.text:
• SQL Server Data Tools (SSDT) – for database development
  • SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) – for managing, deploying, and monitoring databases

docs.title: Analytics and Reporting Tools
docs.text:
• SQL Server Analysis Services (SSAS) – for online analytical processing (OLAP)
  • SQL Server Reporting Services (SSRS) – for reporting and data visualization
  • Machine Learning Services – introduced in SQL Server 2016 (originally as R Services)

docs.title: SQL Server Editions
docs.text: SQL Server comes in several editions tailored to different needs. The main editions include:

docs.title: Free Editions
docs.text:
• Developer Edition: Full-featured, for development and testing only.
  • Express Edition: Lightweight, ideal for small applications. Limited to 10 GB of storage.

docs.title: Paid Editions
docs.text:
• Enterprise Edition: Full set of features for mission-critical applications and large-scale performance.
  • Standard Edition: Subset of Enterprise features. Includes limitations on:
    • Number of processor cores
    • Memory capacity

For more details, refer to the SQL Server 2022 Editions documentation.

docs.title: 001.002.Install SQL Server
docs.text: Home / 001_Getting_Started_with_SQL_Server / 001.002.Install_SQL_Server

docs.title: Download SQL Server 2022
docs.text:
To download SQL Server 2022, click the link below: Download SQL Server

Microsoft offers several editions of SQL Server. For learning purposes, download the Developer Edition.

docs.title: Steps to Download SQL Server 2022
docs.text:
1. Launch the Downloader

    Select Download Media. This option allows you to download the setup files and install SQL Server later.

  2. Choose Download Location

    Select a folder to store the installation files and click Download.

  3. Wait for Download

    The downloader will begin downloading the installation files. This may take several minutes depending on your internet speed.

  4. Open the Download Folder

    Once the download is complete, open the folder containing the file.

  5. Launch the Installer

    Run the SQLServer2022-DEV-x64-ENU file. It will extract the contents and start the installation process.

docs.title: Installation Steps
docs.text:
1. Start the Installer

    In the SQL Server Installation Center, click Installation on the left pane.

  2. Choose Edition

    Select Developer Edition and click Next.

  3. Accept License Terms

    Check "I accept the license terms." and click Next.

  4. Microsoft Updates

    (Optional) Uncheck "Use Microsoft Update to check for updates" and click Next.

  5. Install Rules Check

    The installer checks for prerequisites. If no errors appear, click Next.

  6. Optional Extensions

    Uncheck Aruzé extension for SQL Server (if applicable).

  7. Select Features

    Choose Database Engine Services and click Next.

  8. Instance Configuration

    Accept the default instance ID MSSQLSERVER or change if needed, then click Next.

  9. Server Configuration

    Use the default Service Accounts and Collation settings. Click Next.

  10. Database Engine Configuration

    • Select Mixed Mode (SQL Server authentication and Windows authentication).
    • Enter and confirm the SA (System Administrator) password.
    • Click Add Current User to make yourself a SQL Server administrator.
    • Click Next.

    Be sure to store the SA password in a secure place.

  11. Install Progress

    The installer will show the installation progress.

  12. Complete Installation

    After installation, click Close to exit.

Congratulations! You have successfully installed SQL Server 2022 Developer Edition.

docs.title: Install SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)
docs.text:
To interact with SQL Server, use SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS) — a free tool provided by Microsoft.

SSMS allows you to query, design, configure, and manage SQL Server instances both locally and remotely.

docs.title: Download SSMS
docs.text:
Download SSMS from the Microsoft website: Download SQL Server Management Studio

  1. Launch Installer

Run the file SSMS-Setup-ENU.exe.

  1. Click Install

Start the installation by clicking the Install button.

  1. Wait for Installation

The setup process may take a few minutes.

  1. Finish Installation

Once complete, click Close.

docs.title: 001.003.Connect to the SQL Server
docs.text: Home / 001_Getting_Started_with_SQL_Server / 001.003.Connect_to_the_SQL_Server

docs.title: 1. Connect to SQL Server Using SSMS
docs.text: To connect to SQL Server using Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio, follow these steps:

docs.title: Step 1: Launch SSMS
docs.text: Open Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio from your Start menu or desktop shortcut.

docs.title: Step 2: Open the Connection Dialog
docs.text: In Object Explorer, click Connect > Database Engine.

docs.title: Step 3: Enter Server Connection Details
docs.text:
• Server Type: Database Engine
  • Server Name: localhost
  • Authentication: SQL Server Authentication
  • Login: sa
  • Password: (Enter the password you set during installation)
  • Remember Password: Check
  • Encryption: Optional

Click Connect.

If successful, you’ll see the Object Explorer panel listing your SQL Server instance.

docs.title: 2. Execute a Query
docs.text: Follow these steps to execute a query:

docs.title: Step 1: Open a New Query Window
docs.text: In Object Explorer, right-click the connected server node (e.g., localhost (SQL Server...)) and select New Query.

docs.title: Step 2: Enter the SQL Query
docs.text:
SELECT @@VERSION;

This query returns the version of SQL Server currently running.

docs.title: Step 3: Run the Query
docs.text:
Click the Execute button or press F5.

The Results window will display the SQL Server version.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: You’ve now successfully connected to a SQL Server instance and executed a query using SQL Server Management Studio.

docs.title: 001.004.SQL Server Sample Database
docs.text: Home / 001_Getting_Started_with_SQL_Server / 001.004.SQL_Server_Sample_Database

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
This tutorial introduces the BikeStores sample database for SQL Server. It includes two schemas:

  • sales
  • production

These schemas contain a total of nine tables.

docs.title: 2. Database Diagram
docs.text: The database is logically separated into sales-related and production-related data.

docs.title: 3.1 sales.stores
docs.text:
Stores information about each retail store including contact details and address.

CREATE TABLE sales.stores (
 store_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 store_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL,
 phone VARCHAR (25),
 email VARCHAR (255),
 street VARCHAR (255),
 city VARCHAR (255),
 state VARCHAR (10),
 zip_code VARCHAR (5)
);

docs.title: 3.2 sales.staffs
docs.text:
Contains information about store staff including their role, manager relationships, and store association.

CREATE TABLE sales.staffs (
 staff_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 first_name VARCHAR (50) NOT NULL,
 last_name VARCHAR (50) NOT NULL,
 email VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
 phone VARCHAR (25),
 active TINYINT NOT NULL,
 store_id INT NOT NULL,
 manager_id INT,
 FOREIGN KEY (store_id) REFERENCES sales.stores (store_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (manager_id) REFERENCES sales.staffs (staff_id) ON DELETE NO ACTION ON UPDATE NO ACTION
);

docs.title: 3.3 sales.customers
docs.text:
Stores personal and contact details for customers.

CREATE TABLE sales.customers (
 customer_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 first_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL,
 last_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL,
 phone VARCHAR (25),
 email VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL,
 street VARCHAR (255),
 city VARCHAR (50),
 state VARCHAR (25),
 zip_code VARCHAR (5)
);

docs.title: 3.4 sales.orders
docs.text:
Represents the sales order header, including customer, store, staff, and order statuses.

CREATE TABLE sales.orders (
 order_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 customer_id INT,
 order_status TINYINT NOT NULL,  -- 1 = Pending; 2 = Processing; 3 = Rejected; 4 = Completed
 order_date DATE NOT NULL,
 required_date DATE NOT NULL,
 shipped_date DATE,
 store_id INT NOT NULL,
 staff_id INT NOT NULL,
 FOREIGN KEY (customer_id) REFERENCES sales.customers (customer_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (store_id) REFERENCES sales.stores (store_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (staff_id) REFERENCES sales.staffs (staff_id) ON DELETE NO ACTION ON UPDATE NO ACTION
);

docs.title: 3.5 sales.order_items
docs.text:
Details each line item within a sales order, including product, quantity, and pricing.

CREATE TABLE sales.order_items (
 order_id INT,
 item_id INT,
 product_id INT NOT NULL,
 quantity INT NOT NULL,
 list_price DECIMAL (10, 2) NOT NULL,
 discount DECIMAL (4, 2) NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
 PRIMARY KEY (order_id, item_id),
 FOREIGN KEY (order_id) REFERENCES sales.orders (order_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (product_id) REFERENCES production.products (product_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE
);

docs.title: 3.6 production.categories
docs.text:
Stores product category types such as electric bikes, comfort bikes, etc.

CREATE TABLE production.categories (
 category_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 category_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL
);

docs.title: 3.7 production.brands
docs.text:
Stores information about bicycle brands.

CREATE TABLE production.brands (
 brand_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 brand_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL
);

docs.title: 3.8 production.products
docs.text:
Includes details for each product such as name, model year, brand, and category.

CREATE TABLE production.products (
 product_id INT IDENTITY (1, 1) PRIMARY KEY,
 product_name VARCHAR (255) NOT NULL,
 brand_id INT NOT NULL,
 category_id INT NOT NULL,
 model_year SMALLINT NOT NULL,
 list_price DECIMAL (10, 2) NOT NULL,
 FOREIGN KEY (category_id) REFERENCES production.categories (category_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (brand_id) REFERENCES production.brands (brand_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE
);

docs.title: 3.9 production.stocks
docs.text:
Keeps track of product inventory at each store.

CREATE TABLE production.stocks (
 store_id INT,
 product_id INT,
 quantity INT,
 PRIMARY KEY (store_id, product_id),
 FOREIGN KEY (store_id) REFERENCES sales.stores (store_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE,
 FOREIGN KEY (product_id) REFERENCES production.products (product_id) ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE
);

docs.title: 4. Sample Database Script
docs.text:
You can download the full SQL script to install the sample database:

SQL-Server-Sample-Database

docs.title: 5. Conclusion
docs.text: You are now familiar with the BikeStores sample database structure and its tables. You can use this database to practice and explore SQL Server queries and data relationships.

docs.title: 001.005.Load Sample Database
docs.text: Home / 001_Getting_Started_with_SQL_Server / 001.005.Load_Sample_Database

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Download the sample database ZIP file: ➤ SQL-Server-Sample-Database

  2. Unzip the file to extract the following SQL script files:

    • BikeStores Sample Database - create objects.sql – Creates schemas and tables.
    • BikeStores Sample Database - load data.sql – Inserts data into the tables.
    • BikeStores Sample Database - drop all objects.sql – Drops tables and schemas (for refresh/reset purposes).

docs.title: Step 1: Connect to SQL Server
docs.text:
• Open SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS).
  • Choose the server name, enter the username and password, then click Connect.

docs.title: Step 2: Create a New Database
docs.text:
• In Object Explorer, right-click the Databases node.
  • Select New Database….

docs.title: Step 3: Name the Database
docs.text:
• Enter BikeStores as the Database name.
  • Click OK to create the database.

docs.title: Step 4: Verify Database Creation
docs.text: • Ensure the BikeStores database appears under the Databases node.

docs.title: Step 5: Open the Script
docs.text:
• From the top menu, select File > Open > File….
  • Choose BikeStores Sample Database - create objects.sql.

docs.title: Step 6: Execute the Script
docs.text:
• Click the Execute button to run the script.
  • Confirm that the script executed successfully via the messages pane.

docs.title: Step 7: Verify Object Creation
docs.text:
• In Object Explorer, expand BikeStores > Tables.
  • You should see schemas and tables created.

docs.title: Step 8: Open the Data Script
docs.text:
• Go to File > Open > File… again.
  • Select BikeStores Sample Database - load data.sql.

docs.title: Step 9: Execute the Script
docs.text:
• Click the Execute button.
  • Confirm that the data was loaded successfully from the messages pane.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
You have successfully:

  • Created the BikeStores database.
  • Created schemas and tables using the provided SQL script.
  • Loaded sample data into the tables.

You can now begin querying and exploring the BikeStores sample database.
